choices.text: Vmax in unchanged, Km is increased
Vmax is decreased, Km is unchanged
Km is increased, Vmax is increased
Both Km and Vmax are increased

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the effect of the inhibitor (shown in the image) on Vmax and Km of the enzyme?
questions.solution:
Enzyme inhibition

Such inhibition is either competitive or noncompetitive.

i. Competitive (equilibrium type): The drug being structurally similar competes with the normal substrate for the catalytic binding site of the enzyme so that the product is not formed or a nonfunctional product is formed, and a new equilibrium is achieved in the presence of the drug. Such inhibitors increase the kM but the Vmax remains unchanged.

A nonequilibrium type of enzyme inhibition can also occur with drugs which react with the same catalytic site of the enzyme but either form strong covalent bonds or have such high affinity for the enzyme that the normal substrate is not able to displace the inhibitor. e.g.

Organophosphates react covalently with the esteretic site of the enzyme cholinesterase. In these situations, kM is increased and Vmax is reduced.

ii. Noncompetitive: The inhibitor reacts with an adjacent site and not with the catalytic site, but alters the enzyme in such a way that it loses its catalytic property. Thus, kM is unchanged but Vmax is reduced.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 47

questions.text: A patient on digoxin, potassium chloride, clarithromycin, atenolol and triamterene developed ventricular arrhythmia. Serum digoxin levels were raised. Which of the following medications might be responsible for it?
questions.solution:
CYP3A4/5 Carryout biotransformation of largest number (nearly 50%) of drugs. In addition to liver, these isoforms are expressed in intestine (responsible for first pass metabolism at this site) and kidney as well.

Inhibition of this isoenzyme by erythromycin, clarithromycin, ketoconazole, itraconazole is responsible for the important drug interaction with terfenadine, astemizole and cisapride which are its substrates. Verapamil, ritonavir and a constituent of grape fruit juice are other important inhibitors.

  • Mnemonic

Enzyme inhibitors[Virat Kohli Can't Call Every Indians]

Valproate

Ketoconazole

Cimetidine

Ciprofloxacin/Clarithromycin

Erythromycin

INH

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 29

questions.text: The graph shows below the relationship between Dose (Log) and the response of two drugs (Drug A and B). Which of these drugs has the highest potency?
questions.solution:
Drug potency and efficacy

The position of DRC on the dose axis is the index of drug potency which refers to the amount of drug needed to produce a certain response.

A DRC positioned rightward indicates lower potency. Relative potency is often more meaningful than absolute potency, and is generally defined by comparing the dose (concentration) of the two agonists at which they elicit half maximal response (EC50).

Drug potency is clearly a factor in choosing the dose of a drug.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 63-64

choices.text: Half-life doubles and CP remains same
Half-life remains same and Cp doubles

questions.text: A drug's half-life and plasma concentration follows first order kinetics. What would happen if the dose is doubled?
questions.solution:
First order kinetics: The rate of elimination is directly proportional to the drug concentration; CL remains constant; or a constant fraction of the drug present in the body is eliminated in unit time. This applies to majority of drugs

which do not saturate the elimination processes (transporters, enzymes, blood flow, etc.) over the therapeutic concentration range. However, if the dose is high enough, elimination pathways of all drugs will get saturated.

First order kinetics-t½ remains constant because V and CL do not change with dose.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 39-40

questions.text: An elderly woman received a botox injection for treatment of her wrinkles. Which of the following would best explain its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin A and B are highly potent exotoxins produced by Clostridium botulinum that are responsible for 'botulism' (a type of food poisoning). These neurotoxic proteins cause long-lasting loss of cholinergic transmission by interacting with axonal proteins involved in exocytotic release of ACh.

Localized injection of botulinum toxin A (BOTOX) can be used in the treatment of a number of spastic and other neurological conditions like blepharospasm, spastic cerebral palsy, strabismus, spasmodic torticollis, nystagmus, hemifacial spasm, post stroke spasticity, spasmodic dysphonia, axillary hyperhydrosis, etc. which are due to overactivity of cholinergic nerves.

It is being employed popularly as beauty treatment for removal of age-related facial wrinkles. However, incorrect injection or overdose can be dangerous; ptosis, diplopia, facial swelling, dry mouth, dysphagia, dysarthria, muscular weakness and even respiratory paralysis has occurred.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 110-111

questions.text: A patient with COPD and diabetes developed post-operative urinary retention. Which of the following drugs would be best for this patient?
questions.solution:
Tamsulosin This relatively uroselective α1A/α1D blocker (α1A: α1B affinity 7-38 fold) has been found as effective as terazosin in improving BHP symptoms, because α1A subtype predominate in the bladder base and prostate.

However, it lacks the prostatic apoptosis promoting property of terazosin and doxazosin. Tamsulosin does not cause significant changes in BP or HR at doses which relieve urinary symptoms, and it is not used as an antihypertensive.

Postural hypotension is infrequent, dizziness and retrograde ejaculation are the only significant side effects.

It may be a better tolerated α1 blocker for BHP in patients who continue to suffer postural hypotension with terazosin/doxazosin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 156

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency room after poisoning with an unknown substance. Muscarinic poisoning was suspected, and he was treated for the same. What is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANTICHOLINESTERASE POISONING

Anticholinesterases are easily available and extensively used as agricultural and household insecticides; accidental as well as suicidal and homicidal poisoning is common.

Local muscarinic manifestations at the site of exposure (skin, eye, g.i.t.) occur immediately and are followed by complex systemic effects due to muscarinic, nicotinic and central actions.

They are:

  • Irritation of eye, lacrimation, salivation, sweating, copious tracheo-bronchial secretions, miosis, blurring of vision, bronchospasm, breathlessness, colic, involuntary defecation and urination.
  • Fall in BP, bradycardia, cardiac arrhythmias, vascular collapse.
  • Muscular fasciculations, weakness, respiratory paralysis (central as well as peripheral).
  • Irritability, disorientation, unsteadiness, tremor, ataxia, convulsions, coma and death.
  • Death is generally due to respiratory failure.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 122

questions.text: 35-year-old female, diagnosed with open angle glaucoma, was started on Brimonidine topical therapy. After 1 week of treatment, her IOP started decreasing and her symptoms are getting weaned. Possible mechanism of brimonidine in this patient is
questions.solution:
Brimonidine

This clonidine congener is more α2 selective and more lipophilic than apraclonidine. It lowers i.o.t. by 20–27% by reducing aqueous production and by increasing uveoscleral flow.

Allergic conjunctivitis, dry mouth, sedation and a small fall in BP have been noted.

Brimonidine is indicated both for short-term (prophylaxis of i.o.t. spikes post laser/post-surgery) as well as long-term use in glaucoma.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 168-169

questions.text:
A new drug was given to 25 normal subjects in a phase 1 clinical trial. The cardiovascular effects are summarized in the table below:

Which one of the following drugs the new experimental drug most resembles?
questions.solution: Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 143

questions.text:
Responses on isolated perfused heart of frog:

What might be the mechanism of action of test drug?
questions.solution:
Propranolol decreases heart rate, force of contraction (at relatively higher doses) and cardiac output (c.o.).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 158

choices.text: Increased cardiac contractile force induced by nor epinephrine

questions.text: When given to a patient, Phentolamine blocks one of the following:
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine: It is a selective α1 agonist, with negligible β action. It raises BP by causing vasoconstriction. Because it has little cardiac action, reflex bradycardia is prominent Phentolamine This is a rapidly acting α blocker with short duration of action (in minutes). Because of nonselective α1 and α2 blockade, NA release is increased and tachycardia occurs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 148-155

questions.text: Inhibition of which of the following is the mechanism of action of tocilizumab?
questions.solution:
Biological DMARDs

  1. TNF-a blocking agents
    TNF-α plays a major role in the joint destruction in patients with RA. Five drugs etanercept, adalimumab, infliximab, golimumab and certolizumab act as DMARDs by blocking the action of TNF-α. All of these are give subcutaneously except infliximab which is given I.V. These drugs can cause activation of latent tuberculosis. Infliximab is also indicated in Crohn's disease psoriatic arthritis, Wegener's granulomatosis and sarcoidosis.
  2. Co-stimulation inhibitors
    Abtacept     and belatacept act by inhibiting CD80 and CD86 co-stimulatory molecules on antigen presenting cells. Interaction of these with CD 28 on Tcells is necessary for T-Cell activation. These are indicated for RA resistant to combination of methotrexate and TNF-α inhibitors.
  3. IL-6 receptor antagonists
    Tocilizumab     is a monoclonal antibody against IL-6. It is approved for RA in combination with methotrexate. Tocilizumab is also approved now for cytokine release syndrome. Sarilumab is a new IL-6R antagonist for RA.
  4. Rituximab
    It is a monoclonal antibody that depletes B-cells and is used for RA in combination with methotrexate.
  5. Anakinra: It is IL-1 receptor antagonist used for RA.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, page no. 648

questions.text: A pregnant woman was prescribed Indomethacin. What effect could be expected in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ductus arteriosus closure

During foetal circulation ductus arteriosus is kept patent by local elaboration of PGE2 by COX-2. Unknown mechanisms switch off this synthesis at birth and the ductus closes. When this fails to occur, small doses of indomethacin or aspirin bring about closure in majority of cases within a few hours by inhibiting PG production.

Administration of NSAIDs in late pregnancy has been found to promote premature closure of ductus in some cases. Risk of post-partum haemorrhage is increased. Prescribing of NSAIDs near term should be avoided.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 211

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the treatment of motion sickness?
questions.solution:
Motion sickness

Promethazine, diphenhydramine, dimenhydrinate and meclozine have prophylactic value in milder types of motion sickness; should be taken one hour before starting the journey.

Promethazine can also be used in morning sickness, drug induced and postoperative vomiting, radiation sickness.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 183

questions.text: Which of the following polymorphisms predispose a patient to more chance of Drug induced Liver injury due to diclofenac?
questions.solution:
Adverse Effects of Diclofenac

It produces side effects (particularly GI) in about 20% of patients. The incidence of serious GI adverse effects, hypertension, and myocardial infarction are similar to the COX-2- selective inhibitors. Hypersensitivity reactions have occurred following topical application and systemic administration.

Diclofenac is extensively metabolized. One metabolite, 4'-hydroxy diclofenac, can form reactive benzoquinone imines (similar to acetaminophen's metabolite NAPQI) that deplete hepatic GSH.

Another highly reactive metabolite, diclofenac acyl glucuronide, is primarily catalyzed by UGT2B7. Genetic variation that causes higher catalytic activity of UGT2B7 is associated with an increased risk of hepatotoxicity among patients taking diclofenac.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, page no. 697

questions.text: NAPBQI is the metabolite of which of the following drug's toxicity?
questions.solution:
N-acetyl-p-benzoquinoneimine (NABQI) is a highly reactive arylating minor metabolite of paracetamol which is detoxified by conjugation with glutathione.

When a very large dose of paracetamol is taken, glucuronidation capacity is saturated, more of the minor metabolite is formed-hepatic glutathione is depleted and this metabolite binds covalently to proteins in liver cells (and renal tubules) causing necrosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 223-224

questions.text: Anionic and weakly acidic drugs bind to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Plasma protein binding

Most drugs possess physicochemical affinity for plasma proteins and get reversibly bound to these. Acidic drugs generally bind to plasma albumin and basic drugs to α1 acid glycoprotein.

Binding to albumin (which is more abundant) is quantitatively more important.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 25-26

choices.text: Direct stimulation of cardiac contractile force

questions.text: One effect that theophylline, nitroglycerin, isoproterenol, and histamine have in common is
questions.solution:
• Methylxanthines directly stimulate the heart and increase force of myocardial contractions. They tend to increase heart rate by cardiac action. Tachycardia is more common with theophylline, Cardiac output and cardiac work are increased.
  • Nitroglycerin does not cause direct cardiac stimulation but does evoke a compensatory sympathetic reflex.
  • Direct effects of histamine on in situ heart are not prominent, but the isolated heart, especially of guinea pig, is stimulated-rate as well as force of contraction is increased. These are primarily H2 responses
  • Isoproterenol increases heart rate by enhancing the pacemaker activity of SA node.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 244-587

questions.text: Theophylline causes diuresis by?
questions.solution: Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, page no. 735

questions.text: Paradoxical bronchoconstriction seen with ipratropium bromide is not due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
ADRs of Ipratropium bromide:

The unpleasant bitter taste of inhaled ipratropium, which may contribute to poor compliance. Nebulized ipratropium bromide may precipitate glaucoma in elderly patients due to a direct effect of the nebulized drug on the eye.

Reports of paradoxical bronchoconstriction with ipratropium bromide, particularly when given by nebulizer, were largely explained as effects of the hypotonic nebulizer solution and by antibacterial additives, such as benzalkonium chloride and EDTA.

LAMAs cause dryness of the mouth in 10%-15% of patients, but this usually disappears during continued therapy. Urinary retention is occasionally seen in elderly patients.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, page no. 736

choices.text: Inhibits synthesis of Ig E antibodies
Prevents binding of mast cell receptors to IL-5
Prevents binding of mast cell receptors to Ig E

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the mechanism of action of omalizumab?
questions.solution:
Anti-IgE Antibody

Omalizumab It is a humanized monoclonal antibody against IgE. Administered s.c., it neutralizes free IgE in circulation without activating mast cells and other inflammatory cells.

On antigen challenge, little IgE is available bound to the mast cell surface receptors (FcεR1) to trigger mediator release and cause bronchoconstriction.

In severe extrinsic asthma, omalizumab has been found to reduce exacerbations and steroid requirement.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 251-252

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with insomnia and fears she may have "something wrong with her heart". She describes "her heart jumping out of her chest". She feels healthy otherwise and reports she has lots of energy. Lab tests confirm hyperthyroidism. Which of the following is a drug that produces a permanent reduction in thyroid activity?
questions.solution:
Advantages of 131I

  1. Treatment with 131I is simple, conveniently given on outpatient basis and inexpensive.
  2. No surgical risk, scar or injury to parathyroid glands/recurrent laryngeal nerves.
  3. Once hyperthyroidism is controlled, cure is permanent.

Disadvantages

  1. Hypothyroidism: About 5-10% patients of Grave's disease treated with 131I become hypothyroid every year (upto 50% or more patients may ultimately require supplemental thyroxine treatment).
  2. Long latent period of response.
  3. Contraindicated during pregnancy-foetal thyroid will also be destroyed resulting in cretinism, other abnormalities if given during first trimester.
  4. Not suitable for young patients: they are more likely to develop hypothyroidism later and would then require life-long T4 treatment.

131I is the treatment of choice after 25 years of age and if CHF, angina or any other contraindication to surgery is present.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 278

questions.text: A 54-year-old obese patient with type 2 diabetes has a history of alcoholism. In this patient, metformin should either be avoided or used with extreme caution because the combination of metformin and ethanol increases the risk of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Biguanides, especially the older drug phenformin, have been associated with lactic acidosis. Thus, metformin should be avoided or used with extreme caution in patients with conditions that increase the risk of lactic acidosis, including acute ethanol ingestion.

Lactic acidosis

Small increase in blood lactate occurs with metformin, but lactic acidosis is rare (<1 per 10,000 patient years) because it is poorly concentrated in hepatic cells. Alcohol ingestion can precipitate lactic acidosis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 299

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed as T2DM and was treated with an anti-diabetic drug. After few years of treatment, patient complained of defective vision and the optical coherence tomography results came out as depicted. Which of the following drugs would have caused this?
questions.solution:
Adverse Effects; Drug Interactions.

The most common adverse effects of the thiazolidinediones are weight gain and edema.

Macular edema has been reported in patients using both rosiglitazone and pioglitazone

Increased incidence of heart failure of up to 2-fold. This has generally been attributed to the effect of the drugs to cause plasma volume expansion in patients with type 2 diabetes who have an increased risk for heart failure.

SECTION V

Treatment with thiazolidinediones has been associated with a consistent increased risk of bone fracture in women, with some studies also showing effects in men.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, page no. 877

choices.text: Thiazides acts as add on drug with lithium
Thiazides increase tubular reabsorption of lithium

questions.text: A patient on lithium therapy developed hypertension. He was started on thiazides. After few days he developed symptoms of lithium toxicity. What might be the case of this?
questions.solution:
Interactions

  1. Diuretics (thiazide, furosemide) by causing Na+ loss promote proximal tubular reabsorption of Na+ as well as Li+ → plasma levels of lithium rise. Potassium sparing diuretics cause milder Li+ retention.
  2. Tetracyclines, NSAIDs and ACE inhibitors can also cause lithium retention.
  3. Lithium reduces pressor response to NA.
  4. Lithium tends to enhance insulin/sulfonylurea induced hypoglycaemia.
  5. Neuroleptics, including haloperidol, have been frequently used along with lithium without problem. However, sometimes, the combination of haloperidol and lithium produces marked tremor and rigidity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 477

questions.text: A patient was prescribed anti-psychotic drugs following after which he developed Parkinson's symptoms. Which of the following drug could be used for this?
questions.solution:
ADR of anti-psychotic drugs:

Parkinsonism with typical manifestations- rigidity, tremor, hypokinesia, mask like face, shuffling gait; appears between 1-4 weeks of therapy and persists unless dose is reduced.

If that is not possible, one of the anticholinergic antiparkinsonian drugs may be given concurrently.

Changing the antipsychotic, especially to an atypical agent, may help.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 471

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady came to the psychiatric OPD with symptoms of hypomania. There is a history of maniac episode. Now, she is planning to conceive. Which of the following drug should be avoided in the fetus for its high teratogenic potential?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects

Anorexia, vomiting, loose motions and heart burn are common but mild.

Alopecia, curling of hair, weight gain and increased bleeding tendency have been observed. Rashes and thrombocytopenia are infrequent hypersensitivity phenomena.

Asymptomatic rise in serum transaminase is often noted; monitoring of liver function is advised.

A rare but serious adverse effect is fulminant hepatitis; occurs only in children (especially below 3 year). Those with hepatic disease or who receive other anticonvulsant or hepatotoxic drug are at greater risk.

Administered during pregnancy, it has produced spina bifida and other neural tube defects in the offspring; should be avoided.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 444

questions.text: A patient of schizophrenia was started on haloperidol. Next day, he presented with uprolling of eyes. Complete neurological examination revealed no spasticity or any other abnormalities. Visual acuity and ophthalmoscopy findings are normal. Most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Earliest Extrapyramidal symptoms seen with patients is:

Acute muscular dystonias

Bizarre muscle spasms, mostly involving linguo-facial muscles -grimacing, tongue thrusting, torticollis, locked jaw; occurs within a few hours of a single dose or at the most in the first week of therapy.

It is more common in children below 10 years and in girls, particularly after parenteral administration; overall incidence is 2%. It lasts for one to few hours and then resolves spontaneously.

One of the central anticholinergics, promethazine or hydroxyzine injected i.m. clears the reaction within 10-15 min.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 471

choices.text: Decrease the dose of carbamazepine gradually
Increase the dose of carbamazepine gradually
Continue the same dose without alteration

questions.text: 50-year-old male patient, diagnosed with partial seizures, was started on carbamazepine. Seizure is under control and the patient comes for follow up after 6 weeks. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Carbamazepine is the most effective drug for CPS and is very commonly used for GTCS and SPS. However, it can exacerbate myoclonic, absence and atonic seizures.

Carbamazepine produces dose-related neurotoxicity-sedation, dizziness, vertigo, diplopia and ataxia. Use of extended release oral tablets helps to avoid high peaks in plasma concentration and the resultant neurologic symptoms. Hence to avoid dose related neurotoxicity, Carbamazepine should be preferably start with low dose-gradually increase dose till full control of seizures or side effects appear.

Trigeminal and related neuralgias: Carbamazepine is the drug of choice.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 442-448

questions.text: A patient reported to the OPD with severe adverse response to one of the following drug. The physician immediately orders to administer IV Paracetamol, IV fluids and Bromocriptine/Dantrolene. Which of the following drugs would have caused this adr?
questions.solution:
Chlorpromazine is associated with Malignant neuroleptic syndrome in which Intravenous dantrolene may benefit. Bromocriptine in large doses has been found useful.

Malignant neuroleptic syndrome

The patient develops marked rigidity, immobility, tremor, hyperthermia, semiconsciousness, fluctuating BP and heart rate; myoglobin may be present in blood.

The neuroleptic must be stopped promptly and symptomatic treatment instituted. Though, antidopaminergic action of the neuroleptic may be involved in the causation of this syndrome; anticholinergics are of no help.

Intravenous dantrolene may benefit. Bromocriptine in large doses has been found useful.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 472

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with complaints of difficulty in breathing. His ABG reports increased arterial blood pH and bicarbonate, arterial pCo2 in increased. History reveals he is taking a drug which increases his urine output for more than a year for some heart condition which he has. Which of the following drug has the least chance to produce this adverse effect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Alkalosis may occur with hypokalaemia, because more H+ exchanges with Na+ in DT when less K+ is available for exchange.

Adverse effects of Spironolactone

The side effects are drowsiness, ataxia, mental confusion, epigastric distress and loose motions.

Produces dose and duration of treatment related hormonal side effects like gynaecomastia, erectile dysfunction or loss of libido in men, and breast tenderness or menstrual irregularities in women.

Most serious problem with spironolactone is risk of hyperkalaemia, especially if renal function is inadequate. Acidosis is a risk, particularly in cirrhotics. Peptic ulcer may be aggravated; it is contraindicated in ulcer patients.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 633-635

questions.text: A 35 yr old female, a known case of chronic hypertension, visited the OPD for pre-conceptional counselling. Which of the following drugs should be discontinued or changed for this patient?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of ACE inhibitors

  • Hypotension: an initial sharp fall in BP occurs especially in diuretic treated and CHF patients
  • Hyperkalaemia: This is likely in patients with impaired renal function and in those taking K+ sparing diuretics,
  • Cough: a persistent brassy cough occurs in 10-16% patients within 1-8 weeks, often requires discontinuation of the drug - appears to be caused by inhibition of bradykinin/substance P breakdown in the lungs of susceptible individuals.
  • Rashes, urticaria: occur in 1-4% recipients; but do not usually warrant drug discontinuation.
  • Dysgeusia:
  • Foetopathic: foetal growth retardation, hypoplasia of organs and foetal death may occur if ACE inhibitors are given during later half of pregnancy.
  • Headache, dizziness, nausea and bowel upset:
  • Granulocytopenia and proteinuria: These are rare, but warrant withdrawal. Renal disease predisposes to these adverse effects.
  • Acute renal failure: It may be precipitated by ACE inhibitors in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis due to fall in glomerular filtration pressure.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 531

questions.text: Which of the following anti-arrhythmic drug is contra indicated in interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Amiodarone

These are dose-related and increase with duration of therapy. Fall in BP, bradycardia and myocardial depression occurs on i.v. injection and after drug cumulation.

Nausea, gastrointestinal upset may attend oral medication, especially during the loading phase.

Photosensitization and sun burn like skin pigmentation occurs in about 10% patients.

Corneal microdeposits are common with long 0.term use, may cause headlight dazzle, but are reversible on discontinuation.

Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis is the most serious toxicity of prolonged use, Peripheral neuropathy Goiter, hypothyroidism and rarely hyperthyroidism may develop on chronic use.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 578

questions.text: Which of the following drugs act by inhibiting late sodium current in heart?
questions.solution:
Ranolazine

This novel antianginal drug primarily acts by inhibiting a late Na+ current (late INa) in the myocardium which indirectly facilitates Ca2+ entry through Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.

Reduction in Ca2+ overload in the myocardium during ischaemia decreases contractility and has a cardioprotective effect. Sparing of fatty acid oxidation during ischaemia in favour of more O2 efficient carbohydrate oxidation by inhibiting LC3KAT has also been demonstrated.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 600

questions.text: A patient with gout developed hypertension. The uric acid is found to be elevated. Which of the following drug should not be administered?
questions.solution:
Hyperuricaemia

Long-term use of higher dose thiazides in hypertension has caused rise in blood urate level. This is uncommon now due to use of lower doses.

Furosemide produces a lower incidence of hyperuricaemia. This effect can be counteracted by allopurinol.

Probenecid is better avoided, because it may interfere with the diuretic response, particularly of loop diuretics.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 632

questions.text: A 34-year-old Hypertensive man is diagnosed with stage 4 Chronic Kidney Disease with eGFR<30. His doctor wants to prescribe a thiazide diuretic. Which of the following could be best for this patient?
questions.solution:
Metolazone

It is able to evoke a clinically useful response even in severe renal failure (g.f.r. ~15 ml/min), and has marked additive action when combined with furosemide.

An additional proximal tubular action has been demonstrated; PO4 reabsorption that occurs in PT, is inhibited. It is excreted unchanged in urine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 630

questions.text: A known case of alcoholic cirrhosis associated with edema was on long term therapy with a diuretic agent. One morning, he presented to the casualty with complaints of vomiting bright red colored material. Which of the following drugs would have been the cause of this?
questions.solution:
Toxicity, Adverse Effects, Contraindications, Drug Interactions of Spironolactone:

Hyperkalemia is the principal risk of MR antagonists. MR antagonists also can induce metabolic acidosis in cirrhotic patients.

Owing to its affinity for other steroid receptors, spironolactone may cause gynecomastia, impotence, decreased libido, and menstrual irregularities.

Spironolactone also may induce diarrhoea, gastritis, gastric bleeding, and peptic ulcers (the drug is contraindicated in patients with peptic ulcers).

CNS adverse effects include drowsiness, lethargy, ataxia, confusion, and headache. Spironolactone may cause skin rashes and, rarely, blood dyscrasias.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, page no. 458

questions.text:
A drug was tested in the electrophysiology laboratory to determine its effects on cardiac action potential in normal ventricular cells. The results are shown in the diagram

Which of the following drugs does this agent most resemble?
questions.solution:
Flecainide

It is the prototype class IC antiarrhythmic which markedly delays Na+ channel recovery.

It suppresses VES, VT, WPW tachycardia and prevents recurrences of AF and PSVT.

It is reserved for resistant cases of paroxysmal AF and for life-threatening sustained VT in patients not having associated CHF.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 576

questions.text: For prevention of secondary atherothrombotic events, a 54-year-old male patient was put under daily Ticagrelor therapy. Due to an emergency, he was about to be posted for surgery in the Emergency OT. What is the new drug considered as the best treatment to prevent bleeding during surgery for his patient?
questions.solution:
Adverse Effects.

Dyspnea is reported in 17% of patients.

Ticagrelor is asso­ciated with a higher risk of intracranial bleeding than clopidogrel Bentracimab. An antibody fragment that binds ticagrelor and its active metabolite with high affinity, bentracimab is administered as an intra­venous bolus followed by an infusion for up to 24 h. In volunteers given ticagrelor, bentracimab rapidly and completely reversed its antiplatelet effects

Bentracimab is currently under investigation for ticagrelor reversal in patients with life-threatening bleeding or who require urgent surgery or intervention.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 14th edition, page no. 722

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presents with this finding shown in the below image. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the above condition?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects

Bleeding as a result of extension of the desired pharmacological action is the most important problem causing ecchymosis, epistaxis, hematuria, bleeding in the g.i.t. Intracranial or other internal haemorrhages.

Bleeding is more likely when the International normalized ratio (INR) exceeds 4, or interacting drugs/contraindications are present.

Treatment: of bleeding due to vitamin K antagonists consists of:

  • Withhold the anticoagulant.
  • Give fresh blood transfusion; this supplies readymade clotting factors and replenishes lost blood. Alternatively, fresh frozen plasma may be used as a source of clotting factors.
  • Give Vitamin K1 which is the specific antidote but it takes 6-24 hours for the clotting factors to be resynthesized and released in the blood after vitamin K administration.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 669

choices.text: Drug B displaces warfarin from plasma proteins; drug C displaces warfarin from tissue-binding sites
Drug B inhibits hepatic metabolism of warfarin; drug C displaces drug B from tissue-binding sites
Drug B stimulates hepatic metabolism of warfarin; drug C displaces warfarin from plasma protein
Drug B increases renal clearance of warfarin

questions.text: The above graph shows the plasma concentration of free warfarin as a function of time for a patient who was treated with 2 other agents, drugs B and C, on a daily basis at constant dosage starting at the times shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the observed changes in warfarin concentration?
questions.solution:
1. Enhanced anticoagulant action
    1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics: inhibit gut flora and reduce vitamin K production.
    2. Some cephalosporins (ceftriaxone, cefoperazone) cause hypoprothrombinaemia by the same mechanism as warfarin-produce additive action.
    3. Aspirin: inhibits platelet aggregation and causes gastrointestinal bleeding. High doses of salicylates have synergistic hypoprothrombinemic action and also displace warfarin from protein binding site.
    4. Long acting sulfonamides, indomethacin, phenytoin and probenecid: displace warfarin from plasma protein binding.
    5. Chloramphenicol, erythromycin, celecoxib, cimetidine, allopurinol, amiodarone and metronidazole: inhibit warfarin metabolism.
    6. Tolbutamide and phenytoin: inhibit warfarin metabolism and vice versa.
    7. Liquid paraffin (habitual use): reduces vitamin K absorption.
  2. Reduced anticoagulant action
    1. Barbiturates (but not benzodiazepines), carbamazepine, rifampin and griseofulvin induce the metabolism of warfarin.
    2. Oral contraceptives: increase blood levels of clotting factors.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 670

choices.text: Inhibition of Factor II and X

questions.text: The primary mechanism of action of unfractionated heparin is?
questions.solution:
Heparin is a powerful and instantaneously acting anticoagulant, effective both in vivo and in vitro.

It acts indirectly by activating plasma antithrombin III (AT III, a serine proteinase inhibitor). The heparin-AT III complex then binds to clotting factors of the intrinsic and common pathways (Xa, IIa, IXa, XIa, XIIa and XIIIa) and inactivates them At low concentrations of heparin, factor Xa mediated conversion of prothrombin to thrombin is selectively affected. The anticoagulant action is exerted mainly by inhibition of factor Xa as well as thrombin (IIa) mediated conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 663

questions.text: A 65 yr old complained of bleeding gums post chemotherapy for her ovarian carcinoma. Her blood investigations show RBC 3.1 X 106/mm3 (normal 3.5-5.5), MCV 96 fL (Normal 80-100), Hb 8 g/dL (Normal >12), neutrophil count 4600/mm3 (Normal 3000-7000), platelet count 7000/mm3 (Normal 130,000 - 400,000). Which of the following drugs would be appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Interleukin 11

Interleukin 11 is a cytokine that stimulates hematopoiesis, intestinal epithelial cell growth, and osteoclastogenesis and inhibits adipogenesis.

IL-11 also enhances megakaryocyte maturation in vitro.

Recombinant human IL-11, oprelvekin, leads to a thrombopoietic response in 5-9 days when administered daily to normal subjects.

Oprelvekin is approved for use in patients undergoing chemotherapy for nonmyeloid malignancies with severe thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 20 × 109/L), and it is administered until the platelet count returns to more than 100 × 109/L.

The major complications of therapy are fluid retention and associated cardiac symptoms, such as tachycardia, palpitation, edema, and shortness of breath; Also reported are blurred vision, injection site rash or erythema, and paresthesias.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, page no. 756

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can result in the below condition?
questions.solution:
Bismuth subsalicylate

It is thought to act by decreasing PG synthesis in the intestinal mucosa, thereby reducing Cl- secretion. It has some prophylactic value in traveller's diarrhoea (probably due to weak antibacterial action as well).

Dark stools (sometimes mistaken for melena) and black staining of the tongue in association with bismuth compounds are caused by bismuth sulfide formed in a reaction between the drug and bacterial sulfides in the GI tract.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, page no. 931

questions.text: A TB patient on anti-tubercular therapy presents with tingling sensation and paresthesia. He is not a diabetic. Which of the following vitamin supplementation would be helpful in this patient?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of INH:

Peripheral neuritis and a variety of Neurological manifestations (paresthesias, numbness, mental disturbances, rarely convulsions) are the most important dose-dependent toxic effects.

These are due to interference with production of the active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine, and its increased excretion in urine.

Pyridoxine given prophylactically (10 mg/day) prevents the neurotoxicity even with higher doses. Prophylactic pyridoxine must be given to diabetics, chronic alcoholics, malnourished, pregnant, lactating and HIV infected patients, and when high dose INH is used.

INH neurotoxicity is treated by pyridoxine 100 mg/day.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 817-818

questions.text: What should not be consumed in a patient with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis on metronidazole?
questions.solution:
Metronidazole is contraindicated in neurological disease, blood dyscrasias, first trimester of pregnancy (though no teratogenic effect has yet been demonstrated, its mutagenic potential warrants caution).

Cautious use in chronic alcoholics. A disulfiram-like intolerance to Alcohol occurs in some patients taking metronidazole.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 895

questions.text: What is the mechanism of resistance by lactamases to beta-lactam antibiotics?
questions.solution:
The resistant microbe elaborates an enzyme which inactivates the drug, e.g.

  • β-lactamases are produced by staphylococci, Haemophilus, gonococci, etc. which inactivate penicillin G.

The β-lactamases may be present in low quantity but strategically located periplasmically (as in gram-negative bacteria) so that the drug is inactivated

soon after entry, or may be elaborated in large quantities (by gram-positive bacteria) to diffuse into the medium and destroy the drug before entry.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 743

questions.text: A patient who was on warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation is prescribed a cephalosporin antibiotic for treatment of an LRTI. He reports back to the hospital after having developed hemarthrosis. Which of the following cephalosporins is likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
Bleeding occurs with cephalosporins having a methylthiotetrazole or similar substitution at position 3 (cefoperazone, ceftriaxone). This is due to hypoprothrombinaemia caused by the same mechanism as warfarin and is more common in patients with cancer, intra-abdominal infection or renal failure.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 780

questions.text: Intravenous administration of epinephrine to a patient result in a severe decrease in diastolic blood pressure and an increase in cardiac output. Which of the following drugs might the patient have previously taken that could account for this unexpected effect?
questions.solution:
Blockade of vasoconstrictor α1 (also α2) receptors reduces peripheral resistance and causes pooling of blood in capacitance vessels → venous return and cardiac output are reduced → fall in BP. Postural reflex is interfered with → marked hypotension occurs on standing → dizziness and syncope.

Hypovolemia accentuates the hypotension.

The α blockers abolish the pressor action of Adrenaline (injected through intravenous route in animals), which then produces only fall in BP due to β2 mediated vasodilatation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 153

questions.text: Antidepressants have been shown to be effective for the treatment of hot flushes related to hormonal therapies for breast cancer. However, some may inhibit the enzyme CYP2D6, which converts tamoxifen to its active form and thus may interfere with tamoxifen activity. Which of the following antidepressants inhibits CYP2D6 to the greatest degree?
questions.solution:
Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors Paroxetine and, to a lesser degree, fluoxetine are potent inhibitors of CYP2D6. The other SSRIs, outside of fluvoxamine, are at least moderate inhibitors of CYP2D6.

This inhibition can result in disproportionate increases in plasma concentrations of drugs metabolized by CYP2D6 when doses of these drugs are increased.

Fluvoxamine directly inhibits CYP1A2 and CYP2C19; fluoxetine and fluvoxamine also inhibits CYP3A4. A prominent interaction is the increase in TCA exposure that may be observed during co-administration of TCAs and SSRIs.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th edition, page no. 274
